title: No Jungler EVER Helps My Lane, WHY?
body:
I'm sick of it. "You were doing fine", they say... "You were winning", they say. I DON'T CARE, GANK MY LANE. I hate Jungling, and I hate Junglers even more. Junglers never look my way until it's too late, and I can't stand it. When they've AFK farmed or they've ganked the other lanes and lost them.. then they finally decide maybe they should come to my lane? THERE'S 5 ENEMIES, QUICK RUN OVER TO HIS LANE..  HE'S DEAD, THE LAST OUTER IS GOING TO DIE, RUN RUN RUN GO...

You really want to know what turns me into an asshole? THIS. THIS IS EXACTLY WHAT TILTS ME AND TURNS ME INTO AN ASSHOLE.

I understand it's not mandatory for a Jungler to babysit any lane. I don't expect a Jungler to babysit my lane. Do you know what I expect? I expect the Jungler to acquire vision, to track the enemy Jungle. To be ready when the enemy Jungler and Support randomly appears in my lane to gank me. I EXPECT MY JUNGLE TO BE USEFUL AND TO DO HIS JOB. If my Jungler feels he can get the even trade in another lane at my expense, that's completely fine. I'll look at that and think "it's even". I'm not an irrational person. If they think for one second that I'm going to keep my sanity while getting completely fucked over again and again, and it's something that could have been prevented, they have another thing coming.

When the Jungler dies 10+ times in other lanes, that's 10 deaths the Jungler created that can't be made up for anywhere else. That's 10 deaths, that no matter how much farming a solo laner does, he or she can't acquire the gold from in an even lane. To me, personally, I believe if a Jungler dies more than maybe 6-7 times it's unacceptable. Junglers are around enemies less than any other player in the game, therefore it shouldn't even be possible that they are dying more than their laners in an average length game.

I've been Jungling a lot lately, because I felt like the issue is always the Jungler. I'm not someone who likes to be like that, but the past several months I've been losing my mind in this game playing Top lane. Junglers don't ever come Top, it's an isolated island.. but as soon as I begin winning lane, all the enemies are in my lane and no one from my team is there to help me. My laners are facing no one, but they aren't getting towers or objectives. When I look around about mid game, there's 3-5 enemies constantly in my lane and the rest of my team is farming like there's nothing going on. It's horrid, and I can't even begin to understand why it's happening. I'm not particularly strong, and I'm definitely not fed enough to fight many enemies alone probably 90% of the time.

When I play Jungle, it's a completely different story. After switching from Top to Jungle, I had a 68% win rate in roughly 60 games. Junglers have FAR too much impact on games right now. It's not even fair. I can win game after game after game as a Jungler, yet the instant I switch to Top lane, I struggle to win even half of my games. I'm a FAR superior Top laner to Jungle... I never Jungle and I do not like Jungling. I lose my lane maybe once out of 10 games as a Top laner. For some reason however, I do not win as a Top laner. The Junglers in my games are useless and it impacts the game so much that it becomes nearly impossible to turn games around.

I'll likely go back to Jungling, as I really hate losing for no reason. I would like to understand more WHY this is happening however. Why is it that Junglers don't gank top? Is Jungle not a popular role, are these players auto filled? Also, as a side note, I have politely asked Junglers to gank for me. The problem is, almost everytime they'll say something like "OK" and then they'll never come. I'm pretty damn good at wave management, I buy pink wards and use the plants to clear out the enemies wards. Nothing helps. Is the other side of the map literally that important? I really would love to keep playing mostly Top, but I can't find any reason at all to do so.

Here is the reason. You don't know what it's like to actually jungle so you don't see the big picture. 
When I'm jungling I will scan the map while I'm making my clears I will look for ganks with high chance of success or threats to try to help my team. If I scan a lane and they seem to be doing fine and are pushing to enemy team I will focus my time elsewhere. I have in some games been so focused with helping my bot lane then go to dragon to see mid lane open so I gank mid then I see the enemy jungler running to bot lane so I run down to help. All this time I didn't have time to go top lane. And then my top laner wants to say something cute like "guess we don't have a jungler" or "shit jungler does nothing" and you bet your ass after that comment I'm not making top lane even a small priority.

I'm not a jungler, but every high elo jungler I see on streams and stuff always say, "always play around the winning side and never gank the losing lane". Like I said I can't talk from personal experience but this sounds really reasonable to me. If you play around the losing side you're just attracting attention from the enemy team to the weakest link on your team, while they have their strongest link playing on their hometurf. Doesn't sound like a good strategy to me. 

When I'm the losing lane I play passively and ask the rest of the team to focus elsewhere so I can farm in peace and get back into the game.  If the enemy team focus on me I expect my team to focus on the other side of the map and try to snowball the winning lanes and hopefully secure more objectives than the enemy can take from my lane. As the losing lane I'll be doing more stalling the enemy as they waste time trying to kill me instead of trying to stop the strong lane on my team. Plus, the last thing I want when I'm behind is for my team to try and make plays around me when I'm frankly in no position to follow up.

Depends on how bad the lane is losing. As a jungler, you can influence and reset the losing lane if it is still in its early stages. If one of your lanes died once and you see an opportunity to gank successfully (net a kill or cause enemies to burn resources), I would personally go for it just to balance things out again (especially if it was bot lane). 

For another thing, it notifies the enemy lane to acknowledge that they have an enemy jungler keeping an eye on that lane, resulting in the enemy lane to be less likely to continue to aggressively force another fight, giving you the opportunity to gank the winning lanes. Call it a mind-trick of sorts and it have a tendency to work.

As a jungler, I will do my best to show up. Even if it means scaring off the enemy just a little bit when they get pushy. The only reason I would never gank is if my team is pushing too hard and doesn't give me enough security to successfully dive without giving out a death as well. 

The worst thing you can do as a jungler is to not show your presence to the enemy team. As a laner, the thing that bugs me the most is that our jungler doesn't even bother to show up to our lane despite us asking for a gank, especially after 1 death. They don't show up until it is to the point where we are losing the lane badly, despite playing safe...all because the enemy team knows our jungler is blind to our lane and able to keep pushing and pushing and pushing to keep gaining an advantage without fear of being retaliated.

If you try to fix the losing lane you are basically taking a big chance of losing your influence on other lanes as well as giving up your experience and gold.

As a jungler, you focus helping the even or even already ahead lanes to snowball for better chance of winning the game.

As mentioned, there is a caveat. If it's early enough to reset it, you should if there is an opportunity. Not all games are going to give you the chance to gank the other two lanes on a regular basis either. Being a jungler is never simple and each game plays out differently. 

It is stupid to continue to gank a losing lane repeatedly. However, it's also equally stupid to not give your losing lane a chance to come back if they are only behind a little bit and you see an opening to make a difference.
